channel.title: MathieuFerment on PrestaShop Developers' blog
channel.description: Recent content in MathieuFerment on PrestaShop Developers' blog

item.title: PSDevCon 2023: PrestaShop News - Where We Are And Where We’re Going
item.description: The PrestaShop Developer Conference happened on the 30th of November 2023. During the day, I was able to present a conference, titled “PrestaShop news - Where we are and where we’re going”. This blog post is a written version of the presentation that I also partially presented at the December Live Update on December 20th.

item.title: PrestaShop ZIP archives repository is available
item.description: In order to make sure old release packages remain available for anyone who needs them, we published a new GitHub repository “ZIP Archives”, which aims to store all published PrestaShop ZIP archives.

item.title: PrestaShop 9 minimum PHP version will be PHP8.1
item.description: The develop branch contains the source code that will give birth to PrestaShop 9. This is the future of PrestaShop: it will be released either at the end of the year 2023 or at the beginning of the year 2024 and must carry on the ambition of the project for 2024. This major version must also embrace the change in the PHP ecosystem, and consequently, it must drop the support of obsolete PHP versions.

item.title: PrestaShop 1.7.8 is now in the extended support phase
item.description: Now that PrestaShop 8.0 is out, here is a focus on maintained branches of the PrestaShop project and what to expect.

item.title: An update on the Symfony migration
item.description: In December 2015, a groundbreaking change in PrestaShop was announced: the introduction of the Symfony framework into the CMS. The goal was to gradually replace PrestaShop’s custom framework with Symfony, and switch its templating system from Smarty to Twig. This project was known as “The Symfony migration”. Looking back, we realize that referring to this project as a “migration” wasn’t really accurate at all.

item.title: PrestaShop Public OSS Demo - May 2021 session
item.description: The project’s fifth monthly public demo session was held and streamed live on May 26, 2021.

item.title: PrestaShop Public OSS Demo - April 2021 session
item.description: The project’s fourth monthly public demo session was held and streamed live on April 28, 2021.

item.title: PrestaShop Public OSS Demo - March 2021 session
item.description: The project’s third monthly public demo session was held and streamed live on March 31, 2021.

item.title: PrestaShop Public OSS Demo - Choosing the pace
item.description: Following the February session of the open source project’s public demo, we now feel confident to set a pace for these events.

item.title: PrestaShop Public OSS Demo - February 2021 session
item.description: Last week, the maintainers team held again a video conferencing for the project public demonstrations session, streamed live on YouTube.

item.title: Second public demo from the maintainers team
item.description: As announced previously, the next session of public demonstration from the maintainers team will happen tomorrow, Thursday 25th of February, at 2 pm CET!

item.title: Announcing public demos from the maintainers team
item.description: Last month, the maintainers team held a special event for the open source project: a public demonstrations session. To better understand what this is about, let’s provide some context.

item.title: PrestaShop 1.7 patch release lifecycle
item.description: Following previous post about Minor Release Lifecycle, here is more explanations about software lifecycle at PrestaShop, focusing on patch releases and the release process.

item.title: PrestaShop 1.7 minor release lifecycle
item.description: The journey of the release of PrestaShop 1.7.7.0 has started. This moment is a nice opportunity to explain PrestaShop’s minor release lifecycle.

item.title: What happens to pull requests after they are submitted
item.description: The PrestaShop project currently (September 2019) has 389 pull requests open and new Pull Requests are opened almost everyday. All of these pull requests go through a thorough process which aims to provide a stable, consistent and reliable software that we all know under the name PrestaShop. Here is this process in details.
